thread.title: U.S. Stocks a Winner in Greek Drama as Investors Shrug at Crisis
thread.title_full: U.S. Stocks a Winner in Greek Drama as Investors Shrug at Crisis - Bloomberg Business

author: Oliver Renick
title: U.S. Stocks a Winner in Greek Drama as Investors Shrug at Crisis
text:
Greece, for lack of a better word, is good.
That’s the indication from the U.S. stock market, which offers bigger returns to investors when Greece is dominating the news cycle than when stories on the debt-laden European country are less prominent.
The Standard & Poor’s 500 Index gains an average 0.6 percent during weeks in which the number of news stories featuring Greece is above the average, according to data compiled by Bloomberg from this year and 2011 to 2012, the last time Greece was on the brink of default. When mentions of the country are below average, stocks lose an average 0.2 percent. That compares with an average gain of 0.1 percent on all weeks.
Perennial drama this year between Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras’s government and its creditors to reach a bailout deal creates an opportunity for positive surprises to drive the market upward, according to Rhino Trading Partners LLC’s Michael Block.
“No matter what, the world will move on from this with little damage done,” said Block, chief strategist at New York-based Rhino. With continuing accommodation by central banks and data showing a gradual economic recovery, “any hint that disaster is not imminent is enough to push us higher,” he said.
Investors may also be looking to history for guidance. In 2011 and 2012, months of negotiations between Greece and its creditors led to a $173 billion bailout to avoid default. During those two years, U.S. stocks posted gains of 0.4 percent on average during Greek-focused news cycles, and lost 0.1 percent when the country was less prominently covered.
Market Swings The rate at which stocks advance is also higher when Greece is making headlines. The S&P 500 posted gains 62 percent of the time during weeks when news stories about Greece were prevalent, compared with advances 46 percent of the time during weeks with below-average mentions.
While stocks may climb when Greece is in the news, it isn’t a clear path upward. Volatility measured by the size of weekly market swings increases when Greece is on the forefront. This year the S&P 500 has swung an average 1.8 percent in weeks with above-average Greek mentions and 1.5 percent in others. That was most apparent in 2011 and 2012, when the benchmark moved an average 2.1 percent and 1.6 percent, respectively.
“The question at the end of the day was really how important was this,” Steve Bombardiere, an equity trader at Conifer Securities LLC in New York, said by phone. “You ask how much was the prospect of something bad happening keeping people out, and it probably wasn’t that much.”
